title: All Onewheel e-skateboards are recalled after reported deaths
description: Future Motion recalled 300,000 boards after previous resistance to the federal safety commission's push for a recall. Four incidents of fatal brain trauma are linked to the self-balancing boards.

title: A Dallas high school football referee ripped off a player's helmet during a game
description: A referee pushed and pulled off the helmet of a student football player after the two collided during a game Friday night. The Texas high school athletic association is investigating.

title: Inside the workshop where presidential flags are lovingly made, mostly by immigrants
description: Philadelphia – city of brotherly love, birthplace of American democracy. And the only place in the world where presidential flags are made.

title: A semitruck crash in central Illinois has caused a deadly ammonia leak
description: The accident caused a large plume of anhydrous ammonia that caused dangerous air conditions in the northeast area of Teutopolis. Officials say there are multiple fatalities.

title: House and Senate race to find agreement ahead of shutdown deadline
description: The House and Senate prepared for dueling votes on two different stop-gap bills to fund the government for 45 days, hours before a shutdown deadline at midnight.

title: Janet Yellen says a government shutdown could risk tipping the U.S. into a recession
description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is sounding the alarm about the damage a government shutdown could do to the U.S. economy. "It's really reckless and will impose immediate harm," Yellen told NPR.

title: Some states pick up the tab to keep national parks open during federal shutdown
description: Don't cancel that camping trip just yet: Utah, Arizona, and Colorado state governments will foot the bill to keep some national parks open — and tourist dollars flowing — during the shutdown.

title: D.C. has a lot of federal workers. A government shutdown would have big impacts
description: The Washington, D.C., region is home to about 400,000 federal employees, plus members of the military and government contractors. In a government shutdown, they face no pay and lots of uncertainty.

title: To prevent gun violence, these peacemakers start with the basics
description: For South Florida's Peacemakers, stopping the shootings begins with helping people with daily needs — from diapers and groceries to medical care.

title: Barbara Hoctor Lynch, former NPR host, has died at 77
description: The former broadcast journalist who spent time hosting NPR's two flagship news shows during the late 70s, died this month.

title: Anger grows over Ukraine's largest Orthodox church, still aligned with Moscow despite war
description: Millions of Ukrainians still worship in Orthodox churches deeply influenced by Russian clergy who support Moscow's invasion, sparking a clash of faith and national loyalty.

title: How the far right could remove McCarthy and why his fate could be in Democrats' hands
description: At least one House Republican, Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz, is publicly threatening to offer a resolution to try to remove the speaker. Here's how that procedural motion would work.

title: New York swamped by record-breaking rainfall as more downpours expected Saturday
description: Heavy rains knocked out several subway and commuter rail lines, stranded drivers, flooded basements and shuttered a terminal at LaGuardia Airport for hours. More downpours were expected Saturday.

title: Baltimore Archdiocese files for bankruptcy before law on abuse lawsuits takes effect
description: Attorneys and advocates say the church is trying to protect its assets and silence abuse victims by halting all civil claims against the archdiocese and shifting the process to bankruptcy court.

title: First Trump co-defendant pleads guilty in the Georgia election interference case
description: A bail bondsman charged alongside former President Donald Trump and 17 others in the Georgia election case pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges, becoming the first defendant to accept a plea deal.
